[[My]212-miss barfoot uncle]4216-my uncle had risen from the ranks but [he]4216-my uncle disliked to be reminded of it . [He]4216-my uncle disliked the commerce by which [he]4216-my uncle made [his]4216-my uncle fortune . [His]4216-my uncle desire was to win social position ; if baronetcies could be purchased in [our]4217-our time , [he]4216-my uncle would have given a huge sum to acquire one . But [he]4216-my uncle never distinguished [himself]4216-my uncle , and one of the reasons was , no doubt , that [he]4216-my uncle married too soon . [I]212-miss barfoot have heard [him]4216-my uncle speak bitterly , and very indiscreetly , of early marriages ; [[his]4216-my uncle wife]4133-his wife was dead then , but [every one]3621-every one knew what [he]4216-my uncle meant . [Rhoda]197-rhoda , when [one]472-one thinks how often [a woman]615-a woman is a clog upon [a man]3627-a man 's ambition , no wonder [they]472-one regard [us]4217-our as [they]472-one do . '[212-miss barfoot]

' Of course , [women]3478-women are always retarding one thing or another . But [men]3461-men are intensely stupid not to have remedied that long ago . '[212-miss barfoot]

' [He]4216-my uncle determined that [[his]4216-my uncle boys]4225-his boys should be [gentlemen]4226-gentlemen . [Tom]243-tom , [the elder]839-the elder , followed [his]4216-my uncle wishes exactly ; [he]4216-my uncle was remarkably clever , but idleness spoilt [him]4216-my uncle , and now [he]4216-my uncle has made that ridiculous marriage the end of poor [Tom]243-tom . [Everard]242-everard went to [Eton]74-eton , and [the school]3929-the school had a remarkable effect upon [him]242-everard ; it made [him]242-everard [a furious Radical]4229-a furious radical . Instead of imitating [the young aristocrats]4230-the young aristocrats [he]242-everard hated and scorned [them]4230-the young aristocrats . There must have been great force of originality in [the boy]4231-the boy . Of course [I]212-miss barfoot do n't know whether [any Etonians of]4232-any etonians of [his]242-everard time preached Radicalism , but it seems unlikely . [I]212-miss barfoot think it was sheer vigour of character , and the strange desire to oppose [[his]4231-the boy father]4208-his father in everything . From [Eton]74-eton [he]4231-the boy was of course to pass to [Oxford]75-oxford , but at that stage came practical rebellion . No , said [the boy]4231-the boy ; [he]4231-the boy would n't go to [a university]4235-a university , to fill [his]4231-the boy head with useless learning ; [he]4231-the boy had made up [his]4231-the boy mind to be [an engineer]4236-an engineer . This was an astonishment to [every one]3621-every one ; engineering did n't seem at all the thing for [him]4231-the boy ; [he]4231-the boy had very little ability in mathematics , and [his]4231-the boy bent had always been to liberal studies . But nothing could shake [his]4231-the boy idea . [He]4231-the boy had got it into [his]4231-the boy head that only some such work as engineering something of a practical kind , that called for strength and craftsmanship was worthy of [a man with [his]4231-the boy opinions]4238-a man with his opinions . [He]4231-the boy would rank with [the classes that keep [the world]3462-the world going with [their]4239-the classes that keep the world going with their sturdy toil sturdy toil]4239-the classes that keep the world going with their sturdy toil : that was how [he]4231-the boy spoke . And , after a great fight , [he]4231-the boy had [his]4231-the boy way . [He]4231-the boy left [Eton]74-eton to study civil engineering . '[212-miss barfoot]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda was listening with an amused smile .

' Then , '[631-her friend] pursued [[her]197-rhoda friend]631-her friend , ' came another display of firmness or obstinacy , whichever [you]4241-you like to call it . [He]4231-the boy soon found out that [he]4231-the boy had made a complete mistake . The studies did n't suit [him]4231-the boy at all , as [others]3608-others had foreseen . But [he]4231-the boy would have worked [himself]4231-the boy to death rather than confess [his]4231-the boy error ; [none of [us]4244-us]4243-none of us knew how [he]4231-the boy was feeling till long after . Engineering [he]4231-the boy had chosen , and [an engineer [he]4231-the boy would be]4245-an engineer he would be , cost [him]4231-the boy what effort it might . [[His]4231-the boy father]4208-his father should n't triumph over [him]4231-the boy . And from the age of eighteen till nearly thirty [he]4231-the boy stuck to a profession which [I]631-her friend am sure [he]4231-the boy loathed . By force of resolve [he]4231-the boy even got on to it , and reached a good position with [the firm [he]4231-the boy worked for]4247-the firm he worked for . Of course [[his]4231-the boy father]4208-his father would n't assist [him]4231-the boy with money after [he]4231-the boy came of age ; [he]4231-the boy had to make [his]4231-the boy way just like [any young man who has no influence]4249-any young man who has no influence . '[631-her friend]

' All this puts [him]4231-the boy in quite another light , '[197-rhoda] remarked [Rhoda]197-rhoda .

' Yes , it would be all very well , if there were no vices to add to the picture . [I]212-miss barfoot never experienced such a revulsion of feeling as the day when [I]212-miss barfoot learnt shameful things about [Everard]242-everard . [You]4250-you know , [I]212-miss barfoot always regarded [him]242-everard as [a boy]4251-a boy , and very much as if [he]242-everard had been [[my]212-miss barfoot younger brother]4252-my younger brother ; then came the shock a shock that had a great part in shaping [my]212-miss barfoot life thenceforward . Since , [I]212-miss barfoot have thought of [him]242-everard as [I]212-miss barfoot have spoken of [him]242-everard to [you]4250-you as an illustration of evils [we]4253-we have to combat . [A man of [the world]3462-the world]4254-a man of the world would tell [you]4250-you that [I]212-miss barfoot grossly magnified trifles ; it is very likely that [Everard]242-everard was on a higher moral level than [most men]4171-most men . But [I]212-miss barfoot shall never forgive [him]242-everard for destroying [my]212-miss barfoot faith in [his]242-everard honour and nobility of feeling . '[212-miss barfoot]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda had a puzzled look .

' Perhaps even now [you]197-rhoda are unintentionally misleading [me]197-rhoda , '[197-rhoda] [she]197-rhoda said . ' [I]197-rhoda have supposed [him]242-everard [an outrageous profligate]4257-an outrageous profligate . '[197-rhoda]

' [He]242-everard was vicious and cowardly [I]197-rhoda ca n't say any more . '[197-rhoda]

' And that was the immediate cause of [[his]242-everard father]4208-his father 's leaving [him]242-everard poorly provided for ? '[197-rhoda]

' It had much to do with it , [I]197-rhoda have no doubt . '[197-rhoda]

' [I]197-rhoda see . [I]197-rhoda imagined that [he]242-everard was cast out of all decent society . '[197-rhoda]

' If society were really decent , [he]242-everard would have been . It 's strange how completely [his]242-everard Radicalism has disappeared . [I]197-rhoda believe [he]242-everard never had a genuine sympathy with [the labouring classes]4259-the labouring classes . And what 's more , [I]197-rhoda fancy [he]242-everard had a great deal of [[his]242-everard father]4208-his father 's desire for command and social distinction . If [he]242-everard had seen [his]242-everard way to become [a great engineer]4261-a great engineer , [a director of vast enterprises]4262-a director of vast enterprises , [he]242-everard would n't have abandoned [his]242-everard work . An incredible stubbornness has possibly spoilt [his]242-everard whole life . In a congenial pursuit [he]242-everard might by this time have attained to something noteworthy . It 's too late now , [I]197-rhoda fear . '[197-rhoda]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda meditated .

' Does [he]242-everard aim at nothing whatever ? '[197-rhoda]

' [He]242-everard wo n't admit any ambition . [He]242-everard has [no society]4263-no society . [[His]242-everard friends]4264-his friends are [nearly all obscure people , like those [you]197-rhoda heard [him]242-everard speak of this evening]4265-nearly all obscure people , like those you heard him speak of this evening . '[197-rhoda]

' After all , what ambition should [he]242-everard have ? '[197-rhoda] said [Rhoda]197-rhoda , with a laugh . ' There 's one advantage in being [a woman]615-a woman . [A woman with brains and will]4267-a woman with brains and will may hope to distinguish [herself]4267-a woman with brains and will in the greatest movement of [our]4268-our time that of emancipating [her]4267-a woman with brains and will sex . But what can [a man]3627-a man do , unless [he]3627-a man has genius ? '[197-rhoda]

' There 's the emancipation of [the working classes]4270-the working classes . That is the great sphere for [men]3461-men ; and [Everard]242-everard cares no more for [the working classes]4270-the working classes than [I]197-rhoda do . '[197-rhoda]

' Is n't it enough to be free [oneself]4273-oneself ? '[197-rhoda]

' [You]197-rhoda mean that [he]242-everard has task enough in striving to be [an honourable man]4274-an honourable man ? '[197-rhoda]

' Perhaps . [I]197-rhoda hardly know what [I]197-rhoda meant . '[197-rhoda]

[Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot mused , and [her]212-miss barfoot face lighted up with a glad thought .

' [You]197-rhoda are right . It 's better to be [a woman]615-a woman , in [our]4268-our day . With [us]4268-our is all the joy of advance , the glory of conquering . [Men]3461-men have only material progress to think about . But [we]4268-our [we]4268-our are winning souls , propagating a new religion , purifying [the earth]4215-the earth ! '[197-rhoda]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda nodded thrice .

' [[My]197-rhoda cousin]4116-my cousin is a fine specimen of [a man]3627-a man , after all , in body and mind . But what a poor , ineffectual creature compared with [you]197-rhoda , [Rhoda]197-rhoda ! [I]197-rhoda do n't flatter [you]197-rhoda , [dear]3530-dear . [I]197-rhoda tell [you]197-rhoda bluntly of [your]197-rhoda faults and extravagances . But [I]197-rhoda am proud of [your]197-rhoda magnificent independence , proud of [your]197-rhoda pride , [dear]3530-dear , and of [your]197-rhoda stainless heart . Thank Heaven [we]1206-we are [women]3478-women ! '[197-rhoda]

It was rare indeed for [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot to be moved to rhapsody . Again [Rhoda]197-rhoda nodded , and then [they]1206-we laughed together , with joyous confidence in [themselves]1206-we and in [their]1206-we cause .

CHAPTER IX

THE SIMPLE FAITH

Seated in [the reading - room]1207-the reading - room of [a club to which [he]1209-i had newly procured admission]1208-a club to which he had newly procured admission , [Everard Barfoot]242-everard was glancing over the advertisement columns of a literary paper . [His]1209-i eye fell on an announcement that had a personal interest to [him]1209-i , and at once [he]1209-i went to the writing - table to pen a letter .

' [DEAR MICKLETHWAITE]251-dear micklethwaite , [I]1209-i am back in [England]58-england , and ought before this to have written to [you]251-dear micklethwaite . [I]1209-i see [you]251-dear micklethwaite have just published a book with an alarming title , " A Treatise on Trilinear Co - ordinates . " [My]1209-i hearty congratulations on the completion of such a labour ; were [you]251-dear micklethwaite not [the most disinterested of [mortals]4284-mortals]4283-the most disinterested of mortals , [I]1209-i would add a hope that it may somehow benefit [you]251-dear micklethwaite financially . [I]1209-i presume there are [people who purchase such works]4285-people who purchase such works . But of course the main point with [you]251-dear micklethwaite is to have delivered [your]251-dear micklethwaite soul on Trilinear Co - ordinates . Shall [I]1209-i run down to [Sheffield]76-sheffield to see [you]251-dear micklethwaite , or is there any chance of the holidays bringing [you]251-dear micklethwaite this way ? [I]1209-i have found [a cheap flat , poorly furnished , in [Bayswater]77-bayswater]4286-a cheap flat , poorly furnished , in bayswater ; [the man who let it to [me]1209-i]4287-the man who let it to me happens to be [an engineer]4236-an engineer , and is absent on [Italian railway]4289-italian railway work for a year or so . [My]1209-i stay in [London]6-london wo n't , [I]1209-i think , be for longer than six months , but [we]4290-we must see [each other]543-each other and talk over old times , '[1209-i] etc .

This [he]1210-i addressed to [a school at [Sheffield]76-sheffield]1211-a school at sheffield . The answer , directed to the club , reached [him]1210-i in three days .

' [[My]1210-i DEAR]3534-my dear [BARFOOT]242-everard , [I]1210-i also am in [London]6-london ; [your]242-everard letter has been forwarded from [the school , which [I]1210-i quitted last [Easter]78-easter]4293-the school , which i quitted last easter . Disinterested or not , [I]1210-i am happy to tell [you]242-everard that [I]1210-i have got a vastly better appointment . Let [me]1210-i know when and where to meet [you]242-everard ; or if [you]242-everard like , come to [these lodgings of [mine]1210-i]4294-these lodgings of mine . [I]1210-i do n't enter upon duties till end of October , and am at present revelling in mathematical freedom . There 's a great deal to tell . Sincerely [yours]242-everard ,[1210-i]

[THOMAS MICKLETHWAITE]252-micklethwaite . '[252-micklethwaite]

Having no occupation for [his]1212-his morning , [Barfoot]242-everard went at once to [the obscure little street]1213-the obscure little street by [Primrose Hill]79-primrose hill where [[his]242-everard friend]1214-his friend was lodging . [He]242-everard reached [the house]368-the house about noon , and , as [he]242-everard had anticipated , found [the mathematician deep in study]1216-the mathematician deep in study . [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite was [a man of forty , bent in the shoulders , sallow , but not otherwise of unhealthy appearance]1217-a man of forty , bent in the shoulders , sallow , but not otherwise of unhealthy appearance ; [he]252-micklethwaite had a merry countenance , a great deal of lank , disorderly hair , and a beard that reached to the middle of [his]252-micklethwaite waistcoat . [Everard]242-everard 's acquaintance with [him]252-micklethwaite dated from ten years ago , when [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite had acted as [[his]242-everard private tutor]1218-his private tutor in mathematics .

[The room]444-the room was [a musty little back - parlour on [the ground floor]1221-the ground floor]1220-a musty little back - parlour on the ground floor .

' Quiet , perfectly quiet , '[1222-its occupant] declared [its occupant]1222-its occupant , ' and that 's all [I]1222-its occupant care for . [Two other lodgers in [the house]368-the house]4295-two other lodgers in the house ; but [they]4295-two other lodgers in the house go to business every morning at half - past eight , and are in bed by ten at night . Besides , it 's only temporary . [I]1222-its occupant have great things in view portentous changes ! [I]1222-its occupant 'll tell [you]242-everard all about it presently . '[1222-its occupant]

[He]242-everard insisted , first of all , on hearing a full account of [Barfoot]242-everard 's history since [they]1223-they both met . [They]1223-they had corresponded about twice a year , but [Everard]242-everard was not fond of letter - writing , and on each occasion gave only the briefest account of [himself]242-everard . In listening , [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite assumed extraordinary positions , the result , presumably , of a need of physical exercise after hours spent over [his]252-micklethwaite work . Now [he]252-micklethwaite stretched [himself]252-micklethwaite at full length on the edge of [his]252-micklethwaite chair , [his]252-micklethwaite arms extended above [him]252-micklethwaite ; now [he]252-micklethwaite drew up [his]252-micklethwaite legs , fixed [his]252-micklethwaite feet on the chair , and locked [his]252-micklethwaite hands round [his]252-micklethwaite knees ; thus perched , [he]252-micklethwaite swayed [his]252-micklethwaite body backwards and forwards , till it seemed likely that [he]252-micklethwaite would pitch head foremost on to the floor . [Barfoot]242-everard knew these eccentricities of old , and paid no attention to them .

' And what is the appointment [you]1224-mathematical lecturer at a london college have got ? '[242-everard] [he]242-everard asked at length , dismissing [his]242-everard own affairs with impatience .

It was that of [mathematical lecturer at [a London college]1225-a london college]1224-mathematical lecturer at a london college .

' [I]242-everard shall have a hundred and fifty a year , and be able to take [private pupils]4297-private pupils . On two hundred , at least , [I]242-everard can count , and there are possibilities [I]242-everard wo n't venture to speak of , because it does n't do to be too hopeful . Two hundred a year is a great advance for [me]242-everard . '[242-everard]

' Quite enough , [I]242-everard suppose , '[242-everard] said [Everard]242-everard kindly .

' Not not enough . [I]242-everard must make a little more somehow . '[242-everard]

' Hollo ! Why this spirit of avarice all at once ? '[242-everard]

[The mathematician]1226-the mathematician gave a shrill , cackling laugh , and rolled upon [his]1226-the mathematician chair .

' [I]242-everard must have more than two hundred . [I]242-everard should be satisfied with three hundred , but [I]242-everard 'll take as much more as [I]242-everard can get . '[242-everard]

' [[My]242-everard revered tutor]4298-my revered tutor , this is shameless . [I]242-everard came to pay [my]242-everard respects to [a philosopher]4299-a philosopher , and [I]242-everard find a sordid worldling . Look at [me]242-everard ! [I]242-everard am [a man of the largest needs]4300-a man of the largest needs , spiritual and physical , yet [I]242-everard make [my]242-everard pittance of four hundred and fifty suffice , and never grumble . Perhaps [you]4298-my revered tutor aim at an income equal to [my]242-everard own ? '[242-everard]

' [I]242-everard do ! What 's four hundred and fifty ? If [you]4298-my revered tutor were [a man of enterprise]4301-a man of enterprise [you]4298-my revered tutor would double or treble it . [I]242-everard put a high value on money . [I]242-everard wish to be rich ! '[242-everard]

' [You]4298-my revered tutor are either mad or are going to get married . '[242-everard]

[Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite cackled louder than ever .

' [I]242-everard am planning a new algebra for school use . If [I]242-everard 'm[242-everard] not much mistaken , [I]0-i can turn out something that will supplant all the present books . Think ! If [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite 's Algebra got accepted in all [the schools]1227-the schools , what would that mean to [Mick]253-mick ? Hundreds a year , [[my]0-i boy]1228-my boy hundreds . '[1228-my boy]

' [I]242-everard never knew [you]4298-my revered tutor so indecent . '[242-everard]

' [I]1228-my boy am renewing [my]1228-my boy youth . Nay , for the first time [I]1228-my boy am youthful . [I]1228-my boy never had time for it before . At the age of sixteen [I]1228-my boy began to teach in [a school]3687-a school , and ever since [I]1228-my boy have pegged away at it , school and private . Now luck has come to [me]1228-my boy , and [I]1228-my boy feel five - and - twenty . When [I]1228-my boy was really five - and - twenty , [I]1228-my boy felt forty . '[1228-my boy]

' Well , what has that to do with money - making ? '[242-everard]

' After [Mick]253-mick 's Algebra would follow naturally [Mick]253-mick 's Arithmetic , [Mick]253-mick 's Euclid , [Mick]253-mick 's Trigonometry . Twenty years hence [I]1228-my boy should have an income of thousands thousands ! [I]1228-my boy would then cease to teach resign [[my]1228-my boy professorship]4303-my professorship that is to say , for of course [I]1228-my boy should be [professor]4304-professor , and devote [myself]1228-my boy to a great work on Probability . [Many a man]4305-many a man has begun the best of [his]4305-many a man life at sixty the most enjoyable part of it , [I]1228-my boy mean . '[1228-my boy]

[Barfoot]242-everard was perplexed . [He]242-everard knew [[his]242-everard friend]1214-his friend 's turn for humorous exaggeration , but had never once heard [him]1214-his friend scheme for material advancement , and evidently this present talk meant something more than a jest .

' Am [I]242-everard right or not ? [You]1214-his friend are going to get married ? '[242-everard]

[Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite glanced at the door , then said in a tone of caution ,

' [I]252-micklethwaite do n't care to talk about it here . Let [us]4306-us go somewhere and eat together . [I]252-micklethwaite invite [you]1214-his friend to have dinner with [me]252-micklethwaite or lunch , as [I]252-micklethwaite suppose [you]1214-his friend would call it , in [your]1214-his friend aristocratic language . '[252-micklethwaite]

' No , [you]1214-his friend had better have lunch with [me]252-micklethwaite . Come to [[my]252-micklethwaite club]4307-my club . '[252-micklethwaite]

' Confound [your]1214-his friend impudence ! Am [I]252-micklethwaite not [[your]1214-his friend father]4308-your father in mathematics ? '[252-micklethwaite]

' Be so good as to put on a decent pair of trousers , and brush [your]1214-his friend hair . Ah , here is [your]1214-his friend Trilinear production . [I]252-micklethwaite 'll look over it whilst [you]1214-his friend make [yourself]1214-his friend presentable . '[252-micklethwaite]

' There 's a bad misprint in the Preface . Let [me]252-micklethwaite show [you]1214-his friend '[252-micklethwaite]

' It 's all the same to [me]252-micklethwaite , [[my]252-micklethwaite dear fellow]4309-my dear fellow . '[252-micklethwaite]

But [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite was not content until [he]252-micklethwaite had indicated the error , and had talked for five minutes about the absurdities that it involved .

' How do [you]0-i suppose [I]252-micklethwaite got the thing published ? '[252-micklethwaite] [he]252-micklethwaite then asked . ' [Old Bennet]254-old bennet , [the Sheffield headmaster]4310-the sheffield headmaster , is security for loss if the book does n't pay for itself in two years '[252-micklethwaite] time . Kind of [him]252-micklethwaite , was n't it ? [He]252-micklethwaite pressed the offer upon [me]0-i , and [I]0-i think [he]252-micklethwaite 's prouder of the book than [I]0-i am [myself]0-i . But it 's quite remarkable how [kind people]1230-kind people are when [one]472-one is fortunate . [I]0-i fancy a great deal of nonsense is talked about [the world]3462-the world 's enviousness . Now as soon as it got known that [I]0-i was coming to this post in [London]6-london , [people]3536-people behaved to [me]0-i with surprising good nature all round . [Old Bennet]254-old bennet talked in quite an affectionate strain . " Of course , " [he]254-old bennet said , " [I]0-i have long known that [you]0-i ought to be in a better place than this ; [your]0-i payment is altogether inadequate ; if it had depended upon [me]0-i , [I]0-i should long ago have increased it . [I]0-i truly rejoice that [you]0-i have found a more fitting sphere for [your]0-i remarkable abilities . " No ; [I]0-i maintain that [the world]3462-the world is always ready to congratulate [you]0-i with sincerity , if [you]0-i will only give it a chance . '[0-i]

' Very gracious of [you]0-i to give it the chance . But , by - the - bye , how did it come about ? '[0-i]

' Yes , [I]0-i ought to tell [you]0-i that . Why , about a year ago , [I]0-i wrote an answer to a communication signed by [a Big Gun]255-the big gun in one of the scientific papers . It was a question in Probability [you]0-i would n't understand it . [My]0-i answer was printed , and [the Big Gun]255-the big gun wrote privately to [me]0-i a very flattering letter . That correspondence led to [my]0-i appointment ; [the Big Gun]255-the big gun exerted [himself]255-the big gun on [my]0-i behalf . The fact is , [the world]3462-the world is bursting with good nature . '[0-i]

' Obviously . And how long did it take [you]0-i to write this little book ? '[0-i]

' Oh , only about seven years the actual composition . [I]0-i never had much time to [myself]0-i , [you]252-micklethwaite must remember . '[0-i]

' [You]252-micklethwaite 're[0-i] [a good soul]1235-a good soul , [Thomas]252-micklethwaite . Go and equip [yourself]252-micklethwaite for civilized society . '[0-i]

To [the club [they]1237-they repaired on foot]1236-the club they repaired on foot . [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite would talk of anything but that which [[his]252-micklethwaite companion]675-his companion most desired to hear .

' There are solemnities in life , '[252-micklethwaite] [he]252-micklethwaite answered to an impatient question , ' things that ca n't be spoken of in [the highway]4312-the highway . When [we]1237-they have eaten , let [us]1237-they go to [[your]252-micklethwaite flat]4313-your flat , and there [I]252-micklethwaite will tell [you]252-micklethwaite everything . '[252-micklethwaite]

[They]1237-they lunched joyously . [The mathematician]1226-the mathematician drank a bottle of excellent hock , and did corresponding justice to the dishes . [His]252-micklethwaite eyes gleamed with happiness ; again [he]252-micklethwaite enlarged upon the benevolence of [mankind]1240-mankind , and the admirable ordering of [the world]3462-the world . From [the club]1242-the club [they]1237-they drove to [Bayswater]77-bayswater , and made [themselves]1237-they comfortable in [[Barfoot]242-everard 's flat]1243-barfoot 's flat , which was very plainly , but sufficiently , furnished . [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite , cigar in mouth , threw [his]252-micklethwaite legs over the side of the easy - chair in which [he]252-micklethwaite was sitting .

' Now , '[252-micklethwaite] [he]252-micklethwaite began gravely , ' [I]252-micklethwaite do n't mind telling [you]252-micklethwaite that [your]252-micklethwaite conjecture was right . [I]252-micklethwaite am going to be married . '[252-micklethwaite]

' Well , '[462-the other] said [the other]462-the other , ' [you]252-micklethwaite have reached the age of discretion . [I]462-the other must suppose that [you]252-micklethwaite know what [you]252-micklethwaite are about . '[462-the other]

' Yes , [I]252-micklethwaite think [I]252-micklethwaite do . The story is unexciting . [I]252-micklethwaite am not [a romantic person]4314-a romantic person , nor is [[my]252-micklethwaite future wife]4315-my future wife . Now , [you]252-micklethwaite must know that when [I]252-micklethwaite was about twenty - three years old [I]252-micklethwaite fell in love . [You]252-micklethwaite never suspected [me]252-micklethwaite of that , [I]252-micklethwaite dare say ? '[252-micklethwaite]

' Why not ? '[462-the other]

' Well , [I]252-micklethwaite did fall in love . [The lady]4316-the lady was [[a clergyman]4317-a clergyman 's daughter]4318-a clergyman 's daughter at [Hereford]8-hereford , where [I]252-micklethwaite had a place in [a school]3687-a school ; [she]4316-the lady taught [the infants]4320-the infants in [an elementary school connected with [ours]4322-ours]4321-an elementary school connected with ours ; [her]4316-the lady age was exactly the same as [my]252-micklethwaite own . Now , the remarkable thing was that [she]4316-the lady took a liking for [me]252-micklethwaite , and when [I]252-micklethwaite was scoundrel enough to tell [her]4316-the lady of [my]252-micklethwaite feeling , [she]4316-the lady did n't reject [me]252-micklethwaite . '[252-micklethwaite]

' [Scoundrel]256-scoundrel enough ? Why scoundrel ? '[462-the other]

' Why ? But [I]252-micklethwaite had n't a penny in [the world]3462-the world . [I]252-micklethwaite lived at [the school]3929-the school , and received a salary of thirty pounds , half of which had to go towards the support of [[my]252-micklethwaite mother]3571-my mother . What could possibly have been more villainous ? What earthly prospect was there of [my]252-micklethwaite being able to marry ? '[252-micklethwaite]

' Well , grant the monstrosity of it . '[462-the other]

' [This lady a very little lower than the angels]4326-this lady a very little lower than the angels declared that [she]4316-the lady was content to wait an indefinite time . [She]4316-the lady believed in [me]252-micklethwaite , and hoped for [my]252-micklethwaite future . [[Her]4316-the lady father]329-her father [the mother]4328-the mother was dead sanctioned [our]4329-our engagement . [She]4316-the lady had [three sisters]4330-three sisters , one of [them]4330-three sisters [a governess]4331-a governess , [another keeping house]4332-another keeping house , and [the third]4333-the third [a blind girl]4334-a blind girl . [Excellent people]4335-excellent people , [all of [them]4330-three sisters]4336-all of them . [I]252-micklethwaite was at [[their]4330-three sisters house]4337-their house as often as possible , and [they]4330-three sisters made much of [me]252-micklethwaite . It was a pity , [you]4338-you know , for in those few leisure hours [I]252-micklethwaite ought to have been working like [a nigger]4339-a nigger . '[252-micklethwaite]

' Plainly [you]252-micklethwaite ought . '[462-the other]

' Fortunately , [I]252-micklethwaite left [Hereford]8-hereford , and went to [a school at [Gloucester]80-gloucester]4340-a school at gloucester , where [I]252-micklethwaite had thirty - five pounds . How [we]4341-we gloried over that extra five pounds ! But it 's no use going on with the story in this way ; it would take [me]252-micklethwaite till to - morrow morning . Seven years went by ; [we]4341-we were thirty years old , and no prospect whatever of [our]4341-we engagement coming to anything . [I]252-micklethwaite had worked pretty hard ; [I]252-micklethwaite had taken [my]252-micklethwaite London degree ; but not a penny had [I]252-micklethwaite saved , and all [I]252-micklethwaite could spare was still needful to [[my]252-micklethwaite mother]3571-my mother . It struck [me]252-micklethwaite all at once that [I]252-micklethwaite had no right to continue the engagement . On [my]252-micklethwaite thirtieth birthday [I]252-micklethwaite wrote a letter to [Fanny]257-fanny that is [her]257-fanny name and begged [her]257-fanny to be free . Now , would [you]257-fanny have done the same , or not ? '[252-micklethwaite]

' Really , [I]462-the other am not imaginative enough to put [myself]462-the other in such a position . It would need a stupendous effort , at all events . '[462-the other]

' But was there anything gross in the proceeding ? '[252-micklethwaite]

' [The lady]4316-the lady took it ill ? '[462-the other]

' Not in the sense of being offended . But [she]4316-the lady said it had caused [her]4316-the lady much suffering . [She]4316-the lady begged [me]252-micklethwaite to consider [myself]252-micklethwaite free . [She]4316-the lady would remain Faithful , and if , in time to come , [I]252-micklethwaite cared to write to [her]4316-the lady again After all these years , [I]252-micklethwaite ca n't speak of it without huskiness . ' Of course . '[462-the other]

' [You]252-micklethwaite think it natural ? Well , the engagement has continued till this day . A month ago [I]252-micklethwaite was forty , so that [we]4345-we have waited for seventeen years . '[252-micklethwaite]

[Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite paused on a note of awe .

' [Two of [[Fanny]257-fanny 's sisters]4347-fanny 's sisters]4346-two of fanny 's sisters are dead ; [they]4346-two of fanny 's sisters never married . [I]462-the other have never spoken to any one of the engagement ; it was something too absurd , and also too sacred . '[462-the other]

The smile died from [Everard]242-everard 's face , and [he]242-everard sat in thought .

' Now , when are [you]462-the other going to marry ? '[252-micklethwaite] cried [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite , with a revival of [his]252-micklethwaite cheerfulness .

' Probably never . '[252-micklethwaite]

' Then [I]252-micklethwaite think [you]462-the other will neglect a grave duty . Yes . [Barfoot]242-everard was led on to a broad expression of [his]242-everard views .

' [I]252-micklethwaite admire [your]462-the other old - fashioned sentiment , [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite . ' [I]242-everard had an odd thought whilst [I]242-everard was [there]453-there . '[242-everard] [Everard]242-everard leaned [his]242-everard head back , and half closed [his]242-everard eyes . [The listener]632-the listener looked uneasy , but curious .

' Well now , [I]242-everard was staying in the summer with [some friends of ours]4369-some friends of ours at [a little place called [Upchurch]81-upchurch]4370-a little place called upchurch , on [a branch line from [Oxford]75-oxford]4371-a branch line from oxford . ' Now one of [the girls in process of spiritualization]4380-the girls in process of spiritualization was called [Amy Drake]259-amy drake . [You]4396-you foresee the end of it . At [Paddington Station]83-paddington station [the girl]384-the girl and [I]242-everard went off together , and [she]3849-this girl did n't get to [[her]3849-this girl sister]455-her sister 's till the evening .[242-everard]

' Of course [I]242-everard take it for granted that [you]4396-you believe [my]242-everard account of the matter . [Miss Drake]259-amy drake was by no means [the spiritual young person that [Mrs. Goodall]258-mrs. goodall]4399-the spiritual young person that mrs. goodall thought [her]259-amy drake , or hoped to make [her]259-amy drake ; plainly , [she]259-amy drake was a reprobate of experience . This , [you]4396-you will say , does n't alter the fact that [I]242-everard also behaved like a reprobate . No ; from [the moralist]4400-the moralist 's point of view [I]242-everard was to blame . But [I]242-everard had no moral pretentions , and it was too much to expect that [I]242-everard should rebuke [the young woman]4401-the young woman and preach [her]4401-the young woman a sermon . [You]4396-you admit that , [I]242-everard dare say ? '[242-everard]

[The mathematician]1226-the mathematician , frowning uncomfortably , gave a nod of assent .

' [Amy]259-amy drake was not only a reprobate , but [a rascal]4402-a rascal . [She]259-amy drake betrayed [me]242-everard to [the people at [Upchurch]81-upchurch]4403-the people at upchurch , and , [I]242-everard am quite sure , meant from the first to do so . Imagine the outcry . [I]242-everard had committed a monstrous crime had led astray [an innocent maiden]4404-an innocent maiden , had outraged hospitality and so on . In [Amy]259-amy drake 's case there were awkward results . Of course [I]242-everard must marry [the girl]384-the girl forthwith . But of course [I]242-everard was determined to do no such thing . For the reasons [I]242-everard have explained , [I]242-everard let the storm break upon [me]242-everard . [I]242-everard had been [a fool]4406-a fool , to be sure , and could n't help [myself]242-everard . [No one]3554-no one would have believed [my]242-everard plea [no one]3554-no one would have allowed that the truth was an excuse . [I]242-everard was abused on all hands . And when , shortly after , [[my]242-everard father]3748-my father made [his]3748-my father will and died , doubtless [he]3748-my father cut [me]242-everard off with [my]242-everard small annuity on this very account . [[My]242-everard cousin]4116-my cousin [Mary]213-mary got a good deal of the money that would otherwise have been [mine]242-everard . [The old man]4411-the old man had been on rather better terms with [me]242-everard just before that ; in a will that [he]4411-the old man destroyed [I]242-everard believe [he]4411-the old man had treated [me]242-everard handsomely . '[242-everard]

' Well , well , '[252-micklethwaite] said [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite , ' [every one]3621-every one knows there are [detestable women to be found]4413-detestable women to be found . But [you]242-everard ought n't to let this affect [your]242-everard view of [women]3478-women in general . What became of [the girl]384-the girl ? '[252-micklethwaite]

' [I]242-everard made [her]384-the girl a small allowance for a year and a half . Then [[her]384-the girl child]4416-her child died , and the allowance ceased . [I]242-everard know nothing more of [her]384-the girl . Probably [she]384-the girl has inveigled [some one]735-some one into marriage . '[242-everard]

' Well , [Barfoot]242-everard , '[462-the other] said [the other]462-the other , rolling about in [his]462-the other chair , ' [my]462-the other Opinion remains the same . [You]242-everard are in debt to [some worthy woman]4418-some worthy woman to the extent of half [your]242-everard income . Be quick and find [her]384-the girl . It will be better for [you]242-everard . '[462-the other]

' And do [you]462-the other suppose , '[242-everard] asked [Everard]242-everard , with a smile of indulgence , ' that [I]242-everard could marry on four hundred and fifty a year .[242-everard]

' Heavens ! Why not ? '[462-the other]

' Quite impossible . [A wife]514-a wife might be acceptable to [me]242-everard ; but marriage with poverty [I]242-everard know [myself]242-everard and [the world]3462-the world too well for that . '[242-everard]

' Poverty ! '[1226-the mathematician] screamed [the mathematician]1226-the mathematician . ' Four hundred and fifty pounds ! '[1226-the mathematician]

' Grinding poverty for [married people]4421-married people . '[242-everard]

[Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite burst into indignant eloquence , and [Everard]242-everard sat listening with the restrained smile on [his]242-everard lips .

CHAPTER X

FIRST PRINCIPLES

Having allowed exactly a week to go by , [Everard Barfoot]242-everard made use of [[his]242-everard cousin]1165-his cousin 's permission , and called upon [her]1165-his cousin at nine in the evening . [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot 's dinner - hour was seven o'clock ; [she]1165-his cousin and [Rhoda]197-rhoda , when alone , rarely sat for more than half an hour at table , and in this summer season [they]1261-they often went out together at sunset to enjoy a walk along [the river]3616-the river . This evening [they]1261-they had returned only a few minutes before [Everard]242-everard 's ring sounded at the door . [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot [they]1261-they were just entering [the library]3604-the library looked at [[her]212-miss barfoot friend]631-her friend and smiled .

' [I]212-miss barfoot should n't wonder if that is [the young man]667-the young man . Very flattering if [he]667-the young man has come again so soon . '[212-miss barfoot]

[The visitor]439-the visitor was in mirthful humour , and met with a reception of corresponding tone . [He]242-everard remarked at once that [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda had a much pleasanter aspect than a week ago ; [her]197-rhoda smile was ready and agreeable ; [she]197-rhoda sat in a sociable attitude and answered a jesting triviality with indulgence .

' One of [my]242-everard reasons for coming to - day , '[242-everard] said [Everard]242-everard , ' was to tell [you]1165-his cousin a remarkable story . It connects '[242-everard] [he]242-everard addressed [[his]242-everard cousin]1165-his cousin ' with [our]1261-they talk about the matrimonial disasters of [those two friends of [mine]242-everard]4423-those two friends of mine . Do [you]1165-his cousin remember the name of [Micklethwaite]252-micklethwaite a man who used to cram [me]242-everard with mathematics ? [I]242-everard thought [you]1165-his cousin would . [He]667-the young man is on the point of marrying , and [his]667-the young man engagement has lasted just seventeen years . '[242-everard]

' [The wisest of [[your]1165-his cousin friends]4425-your friends]4424-the wisest of your friends , [I]242-everard should say . '[242-everard]

' [An excellent fellow]4426-an excellent fellow . [He]667-the young man is forty , and [the lady the same]4427-the lady the same . An astonishing case of constancy . '[242-everard]

' And how is it likely to turn out ? '[242-everard]

' [I]1267-i ca n't predict , as [the lady]4316-the lady is unknown to [me]1267-i . But , '[1267-i] [he]1267-i added with facetious gravity , ' [I]1267-i think it likely that [they]4429-they are tolerably well acquainted with [each other]543-each other . Nothing but sheer poverty has kept [them]4429-they apart . Pathetic , do n't [you]1165-his cousin think ? [I]1267-i have a theory that when an engagement has lasted ten years , with constancy on both sides , and poverty still prevents marriage , [the State]4431-the state ought to make provision for [a man]3627-a man in some way , according to [his]3627-a man social standing . When [one]472-one thinks of it , a whole socialistic system lies in that suggestion . '[1267-i]

' If , '[197-rhoda] remarked [Rhoda]197-rhoda , ' it were first provided that no marriage should take place until after a ten years '[197-rhoda] engagement . '[197-rhoda]

' Yes , '[242-everard] [Barfoot]242-everard assented , in [his]242-everard smoothest and most graceful tone . ' That completes the system . Unless [you]1165-his cousin like to add that no engagement is permitted except between [people who have passed a certain examination]4434-people who have passed a certain examination ; equivalent , let [us]4435-us say , to that which confers a university degree . '[242-everard]

' Admirable . And no marriage , except where [both]525-both , for the whole decennium , have earned [their]525-both living by work that [the State]4431-the state recognizes . '[197-rhoda]

' How would that affect [[Mr. Micklethwaite]261-mr. micklethwaite 's betrothed]4438-mr. micklethwaite 's betrothed ? '[212-miss barfoot] asked [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot .

' [I]197-rhoda believe [she]4438-mr. micklethwaite 's betrothed has supported [herself]4438-mr. micklethwaite 's betrothed all along by teaching . '[197-rhoda]

' Of course ! '[1268-the other impatiently] exclaimed [the other impatiently]1268-the other impatiently . ' And more likely than not , with loathing of [her]4438-mr. micklethwaite 's betrothed occupation . The usual kind of drudgery , was it ? '[1268-the other impatiently]

' After all , there must be [some one]735-some one to teach [children to read and write]4440-children to read and write . '[197-rhoda]

' Yes ; but [people who are thoroughly well trained for the task , and who take a pleasure in it]4441-people who are thoroughly well trained for the task , and who take a pleasure in it . [This lady]4194-this lady may be an exception ; but [I]1268-the other impatiently picture [her]4194-this lady as having spent a lifetime of uncongenial toil , longing miserably for the day when poor [Mr. Micklethwaite]261-mr. micklethwaite was able to offer [her]4194-this lady a [home]364-home . That 's [the ordinary teacher - woman]4444-the ordinary teacher - woman , and [we]4445-we must abolish [her]4194-this lady altogether . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' How are [you]242-everard to do that ? '[242-everard] inquired [Everard]242-everard suavely . ' [The average man]3477-the average man labours that [he]3477-the average man may be able to marry , and [the average woman]4201-the average woman certainly has the same end in view . Are [female teachers]4448-female teachers to be vowed to celibacy ? '[242-everard]

' Nothing of the kind . But [girls]3460-girls are to be brought up to a calling in life , just as [men]3461-men are . It 's because [they]3460-girls have no calling that , when need comes , [they]3460-girls all offer [themselves]3460-girls as [teachers]4451-teachers . [They]3460-girls undertake one of the most difficult and arduous pursuits as if it were as simple as washing up dishes . [We]4445-we ca n't earn money in any other way , but [we]4445-we can teach [children]3468-children ! [A man]3627-a man only becomes [a schoolmaster]4454-a schoolmaster or [tutor]4455-tutor when [he]3627-a man has gone through laborious preparation anything but wise or adequate , of course , but still conscious preparation ; and only [a very few men]4456-a very few men , comparatively , choose that line of work . [Women]3478-women must have just as wide a choice . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' That 's plausible , [cousin Mary]213-mary . But remember that when [a man]3627-a man chooses [his]3627-a man calling [he]3627-a man chooses it for life . [A girl]3628-a girl can not but remember that if [she]3628-a girl marries [her]3628-a girl calling at once changes . The old business is thrown aside henceforth profitless . '[242-everard]

' No . Not henceforth profitless ! There 's the very point [I]1268-the other impatiently insist upon . So far is it from profitless , that it has made [her]3628-a girl [a wholly different woman]4460-a wholly different woman from what [she]3628-a girl would otherwise have been . Instead of [a moping , mawkish creature , with in most instances a very unhealthy mind]4461-a moping , mawkish creature , with in most instances a very unhealthy mind , [she]3628-a girl is [a complete human being]4462-a complete human being . [She]3628-a girl stands on an equality with [the man]350-the man . [He]350-the man ca n't despise [her]3628-a girl as [he]350-the man now does . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' Very good , '[242-everard] assented [Everard]242-everard , observing [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda 's satisfied smile . ' [I]197-rhoda like that view very much . But what about the great number of [girls who are claimed by domestic duties]4464-girls who are claimed by domestic duties ? Do [you]197-rhoda abandon [them]4464-girls who are claimed by domestic duties , with a helpless sigh , to be moping and mawkish and unhealthy ? '[197-rhoda]

' In the first place , there need n't be a great number of [unmarried women claimed by such duties]4465-unmarried women claimed by such duties . [Most of those [you]197-rhoda are thinking of]4466-most of those you are thinking of are not fulfilling a duty at all ; [they]4466-most of those you are thinking of are only pottering about [the house]368-the house , because [they]4466-most of those you are thinking of have nothing better to do . And when the whole course of female education is altered ; when [girls]3460-girls are trained as a matter of course to some definite pursuit ; then [those who really are obliged to remain at [home]364-home]4469-those who really are obliged to remain at home will do [their]4469-those who really are obliged to remain at home duty there in quite a different spirit . Home work will be [their]4469-those who really are obliged to remain at home serious business , instead of a disagreeable drudgery , or a way of getting through the time till marriage offers . [I]1268-the other impatiently would have [no girl]4471-no girl , however wealthy [[her]4471-no girl parent]4472-her parent , grow up without a profession . There should be no such thing as a class of [females vulgarized by the necessity of finding daily amusement]4473-females vulgarized by the necessity of finding daily amusement . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' Nor of [males]4474-males either , of course , '[242-everard] put in [Everard]242-everard , stroking [his]242-everard beard .

' Nor of [males]4474-males either , cousin [Everard]242-everard . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' [You]197-rhoda thoroughly approve all this , [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda ? '[1268-the other impatiently]

' Oh yes . But [I]1268-the other impatiently go further . [I]1268-the other impatiently would have [girls]3460-girls taught that marriage is a thing to be avoided rather than hoped for . [I]1268-the other impatiently would teach [them]3460-girls that for the majority of [women]3478-women marriage means disgrace . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' Ah ! Now do let [me]1268-the other impatiently understand [you]197-rhoda . Why does it mean disgrace ? '[1268-the other impatiently]

' Because [the majority of [men]3461-men]4478-the majority of men are without sense of honour . To be bound to [them]4478-the majority of men in wedlock is shame and misery . '[1268-the other impatiently]

[Everard]242-everard 's eyelids drooped , and [he]242-everard did not speak for a moment .

' And [you]197-rhoda seriously think , [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda , that by persuading as many woman as possible to abstain from marriage [you]197-rhoda will improve the character of [men]3461-men ? '[1268-the other impatiently]

' [I]1268-the other impatiently have no hope of sudden results , [Mr. Barfoot]249-mr. barfoot . [I]1268-the other impatiently should like to save as many as possible of the women now living from a life of dishonour ; but the spirit of [our]4481-we work looks to the future . When [all women , high and low alike]4482-all women , high and low alike , are trained to self - respect , then [men]3461-men will regard [them]4482-all women , high and low alike in a different light , and marriage may be honourable to both . '[1268-the other impatiently]

Again [Everard]242-everard was silent , and seemingly impressed .

' [We]4481-we 'll go on with this discussion another time , '[212-miss barfoot] said [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot , with cheerful interruption . ' [Everard]242-everard , do [you]242-everard know [Somerset]36-somerset at all ? '[212-miss barfoot]

' Never was in [that part of [England]58-england]4484-that part of england . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda is going to take [her]197-rhoda holiday at [Cheddar]84-cheddar and [we]4481-we have been looking over some photographs of [that district]4485-that district taken by [[her]197-rhoda brother]4486-her brother . '[212-miss barfoot]

From the table [she]212-miss barfoot reached a scrapbook , and [Everard]242-everard turned it over with interest . The views were evidently made by [an amateur]1269-an amateur , but in general had no serious faults . [Cheddar cliffs]1270-cheddar cliffs were represented in several aspects .

' [I]1268-the other impatiently had no idea the scenery was so fine . [Cheddar cheese]84-cheddar has quite overshadowed [the hills]4487-the hills in [my]1268-the other impatiently imagination . This might be a bit of [Cumberland]86-cumberland , or of [the Highlands]87-the highlands . '[1268-the other impatiently]

' It was [[my]197-rhoda playground]4488-my playground when [I]197-rhoda was [a child]3719-a child , '[197-rhoda] said [Rhoda]197-rhoda .

' [You]197-rhoda were born at [Cheddar]84-cheddar ? '[1268-the other impatiently]

' No ; at [Axbridge]88-axbridge , [a little place not far off]4490-a little place not far off . ' [Axbridge]88-axbridge ? Here is a view of [the market - place]4495-the market - place . What [a delightful old town]4496-a delightful old town ! '[1268-the other impatiently]

' [One of the sleepiest spots in [England]58-england]4497-one of the sleepiest spots in england , [I]1268-the other impatiently should say . [The railway]585-the railway goes through [it]453-there now , but has n't made the slightest difference . ' But surely [you]1268-the other impatiently find no pleasure in that kind of thing , [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda ? '[1268-the other impatiently]

' Oh yes at holiday time . [I]1268-the other impatiently shall doze [there]453-there for a fortnight , and forget all about the '[1268-the other impatiently] so - called nineteenth century . " '[1268-the other impatiently]

' [I]1268-the other impatiently can hardly believe it . There will be a disgraceful marriage at [this beautiful old church]4505-this beautiful old church , and the sight of it will exasperate [you]1268-the other impatiently . '[1268-the other impatiently]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda laughed gaily .

' Oh , it will be a marriage of the golden age ! Perhaps [I]197-rhoda shall remember [the bride]4506-the bride when [she]4506-the bride was [a little girl]4507-a little girl ; and [I]197-rhoda shall give [her]4506-the bride a kiss , and pat [her]4506-the bride on the rosy cheek , and wish [her]4506-the bride joy . And [the bridegroom]4508-the bridegroom will be such a good - hearted simpleton , unable to pronounce f and s. [I]197-rhoda do n't mind that sort of marriage a bit ! '[197-rhoda]

[The listeners]888-the listeners were both regarding [her]197-rhoda [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot with an affectionate smile , [Everard]242-everard with a puzzled , searching look , ending in amusement .

' [I]1187-the latter must run down into [that country]4509-that country some day , '[1187-the latter] said [the latter]1187-the latter .

[He]242-everard did not stay much longer , but left only because [he]242-everard feared to burden [the ladies]1001-the ladies with too much of [his]242-everard company .

Again a week passed , and the same evening found [Barfoot]242-everard approaching [the house in [Queen 's Road]18-queen 's road]1274-the house in queen 's road . To [his]242-everard great annoyance [he]242-everard learnt that [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot was not at [home]364-home ; [she]212-miss barfoot had dined , but afterwards had gone out . [He]242-everard did not venture to ask for [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda , and was moving disappointedly away , when [Rhoda]197-rhoda [herself]197-rhoda , returning from a walk , came up to the door . [She]197-rhoda offered [her]197-rhoda hand gravely , but with friendliness .

' [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot , [I]197-rhoda am sorry to say , has gone to visit [one of [[our]4511-our girls]4002-our girls who is ill . But [I]197-rhoda think [she]4510-one of our girls who is ill . but i think she will very soon be back will very soon be back]4510-one of our girls who is ill . but i think she will very soon be back . Will [you]242-everard come in ? '[197-rhoda]

' Gladly . [I]197-rhoda had so counted on an hour 's talk . '[197-rhoda]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda led [him]242-everard to [the drawing - room]3697-the drawing - room , excused [herself]197-rhoda for a few moments , and came back in [her]197-rhoda ordinary evening dress . [Barfoot]242-everard noticed that [her]197-rhoda hair was much more becomingly arranged than when [he]242-everard first saw [her]197-rhoda ; so it had been on the last occasion , but for some reason its appearance attracted [his]242-everard eyes this evening . [He]242-everard scrutinized [her]197-rhoda , at discreet intervals , from head to foot . To [Everard]242-everard , [nothing female]1277-nothing female was alien ; [woman]3471-woman , merely as [woman]3471-woman , interested [him]242-everard profoundly . And this example of [her]197-rhoda sex had excited [his]242-everard curiosity in no common degree . [His]242-everard concern with [her]197-rhoda was purely intellectual ; [she]197-rhoda had no sensual attraction for [him]242-everard , but [he]242-everard longed to see further into [her]197-rhoda mind , to probe the sincerity of the motives [she]197-rhoda professed , to understand [her]197-rhoda mechanism , [her]197-rhoda process of growth . Hitherto [he]242-everard had enjoyed no opportunity of studying this type . For [[his]242-everard cousin]1165-his cousin was [a very different person]1281-a very different person ; by habit [he]242-everard regarded [her]197-rhoda as old , whereas [Miss Nunn]197-rhoda , in spite of [her]197-rhoda thirty years , could not possibly be considered past youth .

[He]242-everard enjoyed [her]197-rhoda air of equality ; [she]197-rhoda sat down with [him]242-everard as [a male acquaintance]1282-a male acquaintance might have done , and [he]242-everard felt sure that [her]197-rhoda behaviour would be the same under any circumstances . [He]242-everard delighted in the frankness of [her]197-rhoda speech ; it was doubtful whether [she]197-rhoda regarded any subject as improper for discussion between [mature and serious people]1283-mature and serious people . Part cause of this , perhaps , was [her]197-rhoda calm consciousness that [she]197-rhoda had not a beautiful face . No , it was not beautiful ; yet even at the first meeting it did not repel [him]242-everard . Studying [her]197-rhoda features , [he]242-everard saw how fine was [their]1284-their expression . The prominent forehead , with its little unevenness that meant brains ; the straight eyebrows , strongly marked , with deep vertical furrows generally drawn between them ; the chestnut - brown eyes , with long lashes ; the high - bridged nose , thin and delicate ; the intellectual lips , a protrusion of the lower one , though very slight , marking itself when [he]242-everard caught [her]197-rhoda profile ; the big , strong chin ; the shapely neck why , after all , it was a kind of beauty . The head might have been sculptured with fine effect . And [she]197-rhoda had a well - built frame . [He]242-everard observed [her]197-rhoda strong wrists , with exquisite vein - tracings on the pure white . Probably [her]197-rhoda constitution was very sound ; [she]197-rhoda had good teeth , and a healthy brownish complexion .

With reference to [the sick girl whom [Miss Barfoot]212-miss barfoot was visiting]1285-the sick girl whom miss barfoot was visiting , [Everard]242-everard began what was practically a resumption of [their]1284-their last talk .

' Have [you]197-rhoda a formal society , with rules and so on ? '[242-everard]

' Oh no ; nothing of the kind . '[197-rhoda]

' But [you]197-rhoda of course select [the girls whom [you]197-rhoda instruct or employ]4513-the girls whom you instruct or employ ? '[242-everard]

' Very carefully . '[197-rhoda]

' How [I]242-everard should like to see [them]4513-the girls whom you instruct or employ all ! [I]242-everard mean , '[242-everard] [he]242-everard added , with a laugh , ' it would be so very interesting . The truth is , [my]242-everard sympathies are strongly with [you]197-rhoda in much of what [you]197-rhoda said the other day about [women]3478-women and marriage . [We]1284-their regard the matter from different points of view , but [our]1284-their ends are the same . '[242-everard]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda moved [her]197-rhoda eyebrows , and asked calmly ,

' Are [you]242-everard serious ? '[197-rhoda]

' Perfectly . [You]197-rhoda are absorbed in [your]197-rhoda present work , that of strengthening [women]3478-women 's minds and character ; for the final issue of this [you]197-rhoda ca n't care much . But to [me]197-rhoda that is the practical interest . In [my]197-rhoda mind , [you]197-rhoda are working for the happiness of [men]3461-men . '[197-rhoda]

' Indeed ? '[197-rhoda] escaped [Rhoda]197-rhoda 's lips , which had curled in irony .

' Do n't misunderstand [me]197-rhoda . [I]197-rhoda am not speaking cynically or trivially . The gain of [women]3478-women is also the gain of [men]3461-men . [You]197-rhoda are bitter against [the average man]3477-the average man for [his]3477-the average man low morality ; but that fault , on the whole , is directly traceable to the ignobleness of [women]3478-women . Think , and [you]197-rhoda will grant [me]197-rhoda this . '[197-rhoda]

' [I]197-rhoda see what [you]197-rhoda mean . [Men]3461-men have [themselves]3461-men to thank for it . '[197-rhoda]

' Assuredly [they]3461-men have . [I]197-rhoda say that [I]197-rhoda am on [your]197-rhoda side . [Our]4522-we civilization in this point has always been absurdly defective . [Men]3461-men have kept [women]3478-women at a barbarous stage of development , and then complain that [they]3478-women are barbarous . In the same way society does its best to create [a criminal class]4525-a criminal class , and then rages against [the criminals]4526-the criminals . But , [you]197-rhoda see , [I]197-rhoda am [one of [the men]4528-the men]4527-one of the men , and [an impatient one]4529-an impatient one too . The mass of [women]3478-women [I]197-rhoda see about [me]197-rhoda are so contemptible that , in [my]197-rhoda haste , [I]197-rhoda use unjust language . Put [yourself]197-rhoda in [the man]350-the man 's place . Say that there are a million or so of [us]4522-we very intelligent and highly educated . Well , [the women of corresponding mind]4532-the women of corresponding mind number perhaps [a few thousands]4533-a few thousands . [The vast majority of [men]3461-men]4534-the vast majority of men must make a marriage that is doomed to be a dismal failure . [We]4522-we fall in love it is true ; but do [we]4522-we really deceive [ourselves]4522-we about the future ? [A very young man]4536-a very young man may ; why , [we]4522-we know of [very young men who are so frantic as to marry [girls of the working class mere lumps of human flesh]4538-girls of the working class mere lumps of human flesh]4537-very young men who are so frantic as to marry girls of the working class mere lumps of human flesh . But [most of [us]4522-we]4539-most of us know that [our]4522-we marriage is a pis aller . At first [we]4522-we are sad about it ; then [we]4522-we grow cynical , and snap [our]4522-we fingers at moral obligation . '[197-rhoda]

' Making a bad case very much worse , instead of bravely bettering it . '[197-rhoda]

' Yes , but human nature is human nature . [I]197-rhoda am only urging to [you]4540-you the case of [average intelligent men]4541-average intelligent men . As likely as not so preposterous are [our]4522-we conventions [you]4540-you have never heard it put honestly . [I]197-rhoda tell [you]4540-you the simple truth when [I]197-rhoda say that more than half [these men]4542-these men regard [[their]4542-these men wives]4543-their wives with active disgust . [They]4542-these men will do anything to be relieved of the sight of [them]4542-these men for as many hours as possible at a time . If circumstances allowed , [wives]4544-wives would be abandoned very often indeed . '[197-rhoda]

[Rhoda]197-rhoda laughed .

' [You]197-rhoda regret that it is n't done ? '[197-rhoda]

' [I]197-rhoda prefer to say that [I]197-rhoda approve it when it is done without disregard of common humanity . There 's [[my]197-rhoda friend]3812-my friend [Orchard]247-mrs. orchard . With [him]3812-my friend it was suicide or freedom from [[his]3812-my friend hateful wife]4546-his hateful wife . Most happily , [he]3812-my friend was able to make provision for [her]4546-his hateful wife and [the children]3512-the children , and had strength to break [his]3812-my friend bonds . If [he]3812-my friend had left [them]4548-they to starve , [I]197-rhoda should have understood it , but could n't have approved it . There are men who might follow [his]3812-my friend example , but prefer to put up with a life of torture . Well , [they]4548-they do prefer it , [you]4549-you see . [I]197-rhoda may think that [they]4548-they are foolishly weak , but [I]197-rhoda can only recognize that [they]4548-they make a choice between two forms of suffering . [They]4548-they have tender consciences ; the thought of desertion is too painful to [them]4548-they . And in a great number of cases , mere considerations of money and the like keep [a man]3627-a man bound . But conscience and habit detestable habit and fear of public opinion generally hold [him]3812-my friend . '[197-rhoda]

' All this is very interesting , '[197-rhoda] said [Rhoda]197-rhoda , with grave irony . ' By - the - bye , under the head of detestable habit [you]197-rhoda would put love of [children]3468-children ? '[197-rhoda]

[Barfoot]242-everard hesitated .

' That 's a motive [I]197-rhoda ought n't to have left out . Yet [I]197-rhoda believe , for [most men]4171-most men , it is represented by conscience . The love of [children]3468-children would not generally , in itself , be strong enough to outweigh matrimonial wretchedness . [Many an intelligent and kind - hearted man]4554-many an intelligent and kind - hearted man has been driven from [[his]4554-many an intelligent and kind - hearted man wife]4133-his wife notwithstanding thought for [[his]4554-many an intelligent and kind - hearted man children]333-his children .
